20260220-the-musical-comedy-murders-of-1.rss_description_html:
Directed by Summer Jones

A creative team responsible for a flop musical plagued by the "Stage Door Slasher" gathers at a mansion during a blizzard for a new audition, believing one of them is the killer. The evening quickly turns into a farcical whodunit, complete with secret passages, disappearing bodies, German spies, and non-stop mayhem, as the frantic group tries to unmask the murderer before they become the next victims.

20260313-a-chorus-line-by-harbor-playhou.title: A Chorus Line by Harbor Playhouse
20260313-a-chorus-line-by-harbor-playhou.venue_address: 1804 N. Chaparral Street Corpus Christi, TX, 78401
20260313-a-chorus-line-by-harbor-playhou.rss_description_html:
A Chorus Line is a powerful celebration of the passion, sacrifice, and determination it takes to pursue a life in the theater. On a bare stage, a group of dancers auditioning for a Broadway show are asked to share their personal stories — revealing the dreams, fears, and struggles that led them there.

As the spotlight shifts from one voice to another, the performers discover that behind every perfectly synchronized number is a lifetime of dedication.Featuring iconic songs like “One” and “What I Did for Love,” A Chorus Line is both thrilling entertainment and an intimate, human portrait of artists chasing the chance to shine. It’s a moving reminder that every performer on stage has a story worth hearing.

It’s a moving reminder that every performer on stage has a story worth hearing.

20260207-gidions-knot-by-the-surround-pr.title: Gidion's Knot by The Surround Project
20260207-gidions-knot-by-the-surround-pr.venue_address: 20318 Huebner Rd, Suite 125 San Antonio, TX, 78258
20260207-gidions-knot-by-the-surround-pr.rss_description_html:
During a parent–teacher conference that spirals far beyond schoolwork, a grieving mother and a shaken elementary school teacher confront the devastating fallout of a student’s death.

The result is a raw, unsettling collision of grief, culpability, and the stories we tell ourselves to survive the unthinkable.

Surround Project Play Dates kick off 2026 with four contemporary American plays never before seen in San Antonio. We’re starting with Gidion’s Knot by Johnna Adams, featuring Eva Laporte and Catherine Babbitt.

We have about 60 tickets available, and we’re offering early access to YOU!

Public ticket sales open in TWO DAYS.

WHAT: Surround Project Play Date — Gidion’s Knot
WHEN: 
 
 

PLAY DATE PRODUCERS | Bonnie Reed & Stu Schlossberg

Run time: Approximately 70 minutes.

Content note for those who need it: This play addresses death by suicide, grief, bullying, and gun violence. Please take care.

Each Play Date includes:

  • A staged reading with complimentary bevvies

  • A San Antonio premiere of a notable contemporary play

  • Space to connect, reflect, or simply observe
 

Play Dates are not traditional staged readings.

They are intentionally intimate, social, and guided by compassion, curiosity, and care for artists and audiences.

We look forward to sharing this first Play Date with you.

Eva + Zach

20260320-our-town-by-en-vivo.title: Our Town by En Vivo
20260320-our-town-by-en-vivo.venue_address: 290 W. San Antonio St. New Braunfels, TX, 78130
20260320-our-town-by-en-vivo.rss_description_html:
En Vivo! Theatrical proudly presents
OUR TOWN
by Thornton Wilder

 March 20 & 21 • The Brauntex Theatre • Downtown New Braunfels
In celebration of New Braunfels Founders Day

Often called “the greatest American play ever written,” Our Town is a timeless reflection on the beauty of everyday life — love, loss, and the extraordinary within the ordinary.

This spring, En Vivo! Theatrical brings Wilder’s masterpiece to life with a uniquely New Braunfels twist. In partnership with the Sophienburg Museum, the production will weave authentic images of early 1900s New Braunfels into the storytelling, blending theatre, history, and community in an unforgettable way.

Featuring familiar local faces, live performances by area musicians and vocal ensembles, and the charm of our historic downtown, this immersive production celebrates where we’ve come from and the enduring spirit of the place we call home.

Join us this Founders Day for a moving celebration of heritage, art, and connection — right here in the heart of New Braunfels.

20260129-wct-new-works-festival-by-waco-.title: WCT New Works Festival by Waco Civic Theatre
20260129-wct-new-works-festival-by-waco-.rss_description_html:
BL!NK
Full Production

BL!NK follows Sadie, an anxious but brilliant coder, and Natalie, her bold best friend and marketing genius, as they dream their way out of a small college town by creating a dating app designed to protect women from predators and data mining. In Act One, they pitch their idea to a skeptical investor, land a game-changing deal, and move to Silicon Valley—leaving behind Sadie’s stagnant relationship. Act Two picks up four years later. Natalie is planning her lavish wedding to Addie and growing frustrated that the now-single Sadie does not have a date. Then Sadie is swept into a whirlwind romance with Jake, a man she meets on their own app. As the wedding approaches, corporate compromises and personal heartbreak threaten their friendship, forcing both women to confront the true cost of success and what they want their futures to be.

 

RIVERBEND

A Staged Reading

RIVERBEND is a modern musical retelling of the Greek myth of Daphne and Apollo. Daphne is an eighteen-year-old high school graduate living in a small Rivertown on the Eastern Shore of Maryland. Feeling her late mother’s absence in town, she plans to take her sailboat for a year-long trip on “The Great Loop,” a journey her mother took when she was her age. However, when twins Aiden and Diana move into town, Daphne’s heart and her plans are challenged by feelings she’s never known. 

 

THE LAST PIECE

A Staged Reading

Amara is shocked when she receives a call from the doctor stating she must come see her ex-husband Andrew, who she has not spoken to in 10 years. She learns of his Alzheimer’s diagnosis and is encouraged by the doctor to spend time with him to discuss their past memories and slow the progression of his disease. As the two reflect on their relationship, they recall their feelings for each other and begin to fall in love again – or so Amara thinks so. When Andrew’s memory begins to acutely worsen and he often finds himself torn between past and present, Amara is hurt as she wonders whether he ever loved her at all. Andrew ends up in the hospital after going missing and Amara finds him. When she learns why he went missing, she is forced to make a decision about their relationship moving forward – one she makes with love and grace, and one that shows how much of ourselves are made up of the fragile memories we hold.

She learns of his Alzheimer’s diagnosis and is encouraged by the doctor to spend time with him to discuss their past memories and slow the progression of his disease. As the two reflect on their relationship, they recall their feelings for each other and begin to fall in love again – or so Amara thinks so. When Andrew’s memory begins to acutely worsen and he often finds himself torn between past and present, Amara is hurt as she wonders whether he ever loved her at all. Andrew ends up in the hospital after going missing and Amara finds him. When she learns why he went missing, she is forced to make a decision about their relationship moving forward – one she makes with love and grace, and one that shows how much of ourselves are made up of the fragile memories we hold.
20260129-wct-new-works-festival-by-waco-.html_synopsis: BL!NK follows Sadie, an anxious but brilliant coder, and Natalie, her bold best friend and marketing genius, as they dream their way out of a small college town by creating a dating app designed to protect women from predators and data mining. In Act One, they pitch their idea to a skeptical investor, land a game-changing deal, and move to Silicon Valley—leaving behind Sadie’s stagnant relationship. Act Two picks up four years later. Natalie is planning her lavish wedding to Addie and growing frustrated that the now-single Sadie does not have a date. Then Sadie is swept into a whirlwind romance with Jake, a man she meets on their own app. As the wedding approaches, corporate compromises and personal heartbreak threaten their friendship, forcing both women to confront the true cost of success and what they want their futures to be.

20260205-the-manhole-by-fronterafest.title: The Manhole by FronteraFest
20260205-the-manhole-by-fronterafest.rss_description_html: “The Manhole” is a campy, surreal, queer coming-of-age dramedy set outside the bathroom of a queer nightclub. Over the course of one uncanny night, Elliot, a young security attendant, encounters figures from his past—teachers, ex-lovers, idols, and even his deceased mother. Blending comedy, camp, spirituality, and emotional revelation, the play explores how queer spaces can become both a sanctuary and a séance—places where we dance with ghosts until we’re ready to let them go.

20260213-beehive-by-tex-arts.title: Beehive by Tex-Arts
20260213-beehive-by-tex-arts.rss_description_html:
The '60s Musical" is a nostalgic journey through the 1960s, told through the lens of six young women navigating the cultural and musical landscape of the decade. The show features a vibrant collection of chart-topping hits, including "My Boyfriend's Back," "Son of a Preacher Man," and "Where the Boys Are". The musical explores themes of love, loss, and the challenges of a rapidly changing world, all while showcasing the iconic music of the 1960s. The show is a celebration of female power and the enduring impact of the music of that era.

 

Created by Larry Gallagher 

 

Run Time: 2hrs with a 15min intermission

20260213-the-savannah-sipping-society-by.html_synopsis: In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate -- and an impromptu happy hour -- and decide it's high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they've lost throughout the years.

20260121-one-day-on-the-camino-by-fronte.title: One Day on the Camino by FronteraFest
20260121-one-day-on-the-camino-by-fronte.rss_description_html:
In the summer of 2025, I walked a portion of the Camino de Santiago de Compostela in Spain and came across a pilgrim from England. It was a day of struggle, a day of empathy, a day of compassion, and a day of shared experiences. This is a moment I’ll never forget. I feel that the experience was an answer to a question that I am continuing to explore.

One Day on the Camino by Rupert Reyes, with Lesley Clark.

20260326-love-letters-by-hill-country-ar.title: Love Letters by Hill Country Arts Foundation (HCAF)
20260326-love-letters-by-hill-country-ar.venue_name: Elizabeth Huth Coates Indoor Theatre, HCAF
20260326-love-letters-by-hill-country-ar.venue_address: indoors at 120 Point Theatre Road Ingram, TX, 78025
20260326-love-letters-by-hill-country-ar.rss_description_html:
We are thrilled to announce our next production, A.R. Gurney’s Love Letters, coming March 26–30 — performed in the HCAF Art Gallery.

This intimate reader’s theatre production follows two people whose lifelong relationship unfolds through letters exchanged over decades. Tender, funny, and deeply human, Love Letters is a beautiful reminder of the power of words and connection.

While our traditional theatre spaces continue to recover from flood damage, we’re proud to bring live theatre into the gallery — blending visual art and performance in a uniquely close and meaningful setting.

Stay tuned — and thank you for continuing to support HCAF Point Theatre as we keep creating, adapting, and gathering.

20260618-the-drowning-girls-by-warehouse.title: The Drowning Girls by Warehouse Living Arts Center
20260618-the-drowning-girls-by-warehouse.rss_description_html:
THE DROWNING GIRLS recounts the story of Bessie, Alice and Margaret, three of the many wives of George Joseph Smith, an Edwardian opportunist who made a living marrying women, taking out life insurance policies for them and subsequently drowning them in their baths. Underwater, three ghostly brides surface from a bathtub to gather evidence against their womanizing, murderous, husband by reliving the shocking events leading up to their deaths. As they make their case, they discover how they have been victimized not only by George Joseph Smith, but also by society at large. Full of rich images, a myriad of characters, a quirky sense of humor and lyrical language, The Drowning Girls is both breathtaking fantasia and social critique. Everyone loves a wedding.

For audiences ages 14+

20260507-violet-sharp-by-warehouse-livin.title: Violet Sharp by Warehouse Living Arts Center
20260507-violet-sharp-by-warehouse-livin.rss_description_html: Based on the true story 1932 Lindbergh Kidnapping Case, Violet Sharp is named for the young British maid working at the home of Anne Lindbergh’s mother. In the wake of the historic kidnapping of beloved aviator Charles Lindbergh’s 20-month-old son, Violet raises the suspicion of the police with a contradictory testimony about her whereabouts to police investigator Officer Walsh. Under pressure from her own personal demons as well as the police, Violet’s efforts to clear her name cannot seem to overpower a growing reputation of guilt.

20260213-doomed-valentines-by-mortified-.title: Doomed Valentines by Mortified Austin
20260213-doomed-valentines-by-mortified-.rss_description_html:
Get ready to cringe, laugh, and cry while total strangers share embarrassing artifacts from their youth.

Whether you’re celebrating or escaping Valentines - spend your evening with us, belly-laughing over tragic love.

Ripped from the pages of real life, Mortified Live (getmortified.com) is a storytelling show where adults share their most embarrassing childhood letters, lyrics, journals, home movies and artwork. Honored by the Austin Chronicle as Austin's "best Wild Card," Mortified is equal parts comedy and therapy. The show has been hailed as "a cultural phenomenon" by Newsweek, and featured on This American Life, NBC's Today Show, Entertainment Weekly, Chicago Tribune, Boston Globe, Talk of the Nation, and more.

Mortified Media operates across the globe, from LA to Oslo, and we produce books, podcasts, and film.

20260327-the-trail-to-oregon-by-gaslight.rss_description_html: The Trail To Oregon is a raunchy, comedic musical about the misadventures of a dysfunctional nuclear family headed down the trail, after a tragic act of god sends them to a new life in Oregon. Based loosely on the classic 90’s video game, and written by the team that brought you A Very Potter Musical and The Guy Who Didn’t Like Musicals, it's an improv filled rollercoaster ride of chaos and hilarity, that may teach you a bit about family along the way.

20260918-the-addams-family-by-wonder-the.venue_address: Suite A-90, Wonderland of the Americas Balcones Heights San Antonio, TX, 78201
20260918-the-addams-family-by-wonder-the.rss_description_html:
It’s every father’s nightmare: Wednesday Addams, the ultimate princess of darkness, has grown up and fallen in love with a man her parents have never met. When Wednesday confides in her father and begs him not to tell her mother, Gomez Addams must do something he’s never done before: keep a secret from his beloved wife, Morticia. Can the Addams family ties survive, or will this “normal” family tear them apart?

20261108-rent-by-entracte.title: Rent by Entr'acte
20261108-rent-by-entracte.venue_address: somewhere in Austin to be announced Austin, TX, 78700
20261108-rent-by-entracte.html_synopsis: Rent is a rock musical with music and lyrics by Jonathan Larson[1] loosely based on Giacomo Puccini's opera La bohème. It tells the story of a group of impoverished young artists struggling to survive and create a life in New York City's East Village in the thriving days of Bohemian Alphabet City, under the shadow of HIV/AIDS.

20260712-brigadoon-by-entracte.title: Brigadoon by Entr'acte
20260712-brigadoon-by-entracte.venue_address: somewhere in Austin to be announced Austin, TX, 78700
20260712-brigadoon-by-entracte.html_synopsis: New Yorker Tommy Albright and his hunting partner are on a visit to the highlands of Scotland when they stumble across the mysterious village of Brigadoon, a quaint hamlet that seems to have stopped in time more than 400 years ago. It is soon revealed that a miracle protects Brigadoon from the modern world by allowing it to vanish at sunset, and only re-appear for a single day every 100 years. When Tommy meets and falls in love with the lovely Fiona, a beautiful resident in this magical town, he must decide whether to return to his old life or stay in Brigadoon — forever.

20260110-xalli-performance-party-by-jump.title: XALLI Performance Party by Jump-Start Performance Company
20260110-xalli-performance-party-by-jump.venue_address: 2600 S. Flores St. 4A San Antonio, TX, 78204
20260110-xalli-performance-party-by-jump.rss_description_html:
Jump-Start celebrates turning 41 with XALLI, a gathering of all manner of artists presenting freshly-created short works of performance.

An indigenous blessing of the space precedes the main event  of Performance Party XLI and then over the courseof three acts, performance artists, dancers, poets, musicians, drag artists, actors, and the undefinable offer a continual communal experience. Eddie Vega, Los MENtirosos, Stephan Gaeth, Kimberlyn Montford, Irene Chavez, Wiley Martinez, Dragonfly, and Marisela Barrera are just a few of the participating artists. Jump-Start’s Flaming Fire-Eaters round off the night.

This year’s PP theme, XALLI, is the Nahuatl word for sand, a timeless earthly element of many sources, colors and formations. Just like all of us.

20260123-lady-puffmuffin-and-the-failed-.title: Lady Puffmuffin and the Failed Marriage by Teresa Stranahan
20260123-lady-puffmuffin-and-the-failed-.rss_description_html:
In this late night queer cabaret and puppet show, we get a glimpse into the quintessential life of Lady Puffmuffin and her perfect nuclear family unit. But as most things that seem perfect, nothing is as it seems.

Juxtaposed with authentic and zany expressions of queer creativity, Lady Puffmuffin and the Failed

Marriage is a dark comedy that explores the absurdity of the ideal "traditional family values" pushed in American society today. Written by Texas Native and Chicago resident Joshua Barrett, and produced by Texas native Teresa Stranahan, this whimsical and almost childlike production blends all the best and weirdest bits of puppetry, comedy, and parody.

20260228-dragons-love-tacos-by-magik-the.title: Dragons Love Tacos by Magik Theatre
20260228-dragons-love-tacos-by-magik-the.rss_description_html:
You know what dragons really love? Tacos of course! They love chicken tacos, beef tacos, great big tacos, and teeny tiny tacos. While a boy and his dog are watching TV, they unexpectedly learn the Do’s and Don'ts of what kinds of tacos to serve dragons, but when the boy throws his new dragon friends a spicy salsa taco party, red-hot trouble ensues! Discover the dietary delights and dilemmas of dragons in this fun-filled production, the award-winning team of Adam Rubin and Daniel Salmieri have created an unforgettable tale of new friends and the perfect snack. Dragons Love Tacos is full of fiery fun for your entire family!

20260305-private-lives-by-bandwagon-arts.title: Private Lives by Bandwagon Arts
20260305-private-lives-by-bandwagon-arts.rss_description_html:
Can’t Live With ‘Em, Can’t Live Without ‘Em.
 
Elyot and Amanda cannot stand being in the same room with one another. So why were they married for three years?
See the classic Noël Coward comedy set for modern times.
Playscript by Noël Coward, production Staged by Matrex Kilgore
 
Featuring Mads Powell (Bandwagon’s No Place To Go) as Amanda, Benajah T. Baskin (Bandwagon’s Someone) as Elyot, Tony Nielson (Penfold’s Spelling Bee) as Victor, and Bella Monette (Palace’s In the Heights) as Sibyl.
 
The Creative Team includes Matrex Kilgore directing, Adriana Fontanéz stage managing, Patrick Anthony designing set and lights, Benajah T. Baskin designing sound, and Norma Cantu designing costumes.
 
 
R for language.
Feature film adaptation forthcoming.

20260320-blithe-spirit-by-aurora-arts-th.title: Blithe Spirit by Aurora Arts Theatre
20260320-blithe-spirit-by-aurora-arts-th.rss_description_html:
Blithe Spirit is a comic play by Noël Coward, described by the author as "an improbable farce in three acts". The play concerns the socialite and novelist Charles Condomine, who invites the eccentric medium and clairvoyant Madame Arcati to his house to conduct a séance, hoping to gather material for his next book. The scheme backfires when he is haunted by the ghost of his wilful and temperamental first wife, Elvira, after the séance. Elvira makes continual attempts to disrupt Charles's marriage to his second wife, Ruth, who cannot see or hear the ghost.

Directed by Jessica Chang and assistant directed by Mario Aguilar.
 
Friday & Saturday Performances
Edith – Perla Regaldo
Ruth – Kalea Bennett
Charles – Joe Martinez
Dr. Bradman – Ernest Pruneda
Mrs. Bradman – Amanda Gomez
Madame Arcati – Debby Ramirez
Elvira – Mariah Treadwell
 
★ Swing Cast ★
Sunday Performances
Edith – Perla Regaldo
Ruth – Kristin McLaughlin
Charles – Bob Caro
Dr. Bradman – Ernest Pruneda
Mrs. Bradman – Amanda Gomez
Madame Arcati – Lisa McGrew
Elvira – Jessica Cooper

20260417-elvis-has-left-the-building-by-.title: Elvis Has Left the Building by Lee County Center for the ARTS (LCCA)
20260417-elvis-has-left-the-building-by-.rss_description_html:
It’s December 20th, 1970, and Elvis Presley has disappeared. No one, not even his wily manager, “The Colonel”, knows of his whereabouts. But the Colonel is all shook up because he has racked up a secret debt — and with the King himself missing, the only way to pay it off is to find an Elvis impersonator within 24 hours. Hijinks ensue as the Colonel takes desperate measures to replace a man who is irreplaceable, all while keeping the prying eyes of a nosy reporter at bay and figuring out what happened to the real Elvis.
 
Directed by Yahva Westbrook.

20260417-elvis-has-left-the-building-by-.html_synopsis: Jason Robert Brown’s powerful and moving song cycle, Songs for a New World — a stunning collection of stories about life, love, and the moments that define us. From the deck of a Spanish sailing ship to the top of a New York penthouse, each song captures a pivotal “new world” moment — when decisions are made, dreams are tested, and hearts are laid bare. With unforgettable music and soul-stirring lyrics, this production is an incredible showcase for passionate, dynamic vocalists and storytellers.

20260116-the-feltdown-a-one-man-puppet-c.html_synopsis: The Feltdown is a comedy puppet show that combines music, improv comedy, and education as Jason takes the audience through his own journey into puppetry, the characters he's created through the years, lessons on building puppets, and performance tips gleaned from years of experience performing improvised puppetry. The Feltdown features more than a dozen different puppets in hilarious scenes and sketches inspired by your suggestions.

20260319-the-miraculous-mixes-of-dj-sant.title: The Miraculous Mixes of DJ Santa Cecilia by Guadalupe Cultural Arts Center
20260319-the-miraculous-mixes-of-dj-sant.rss_description_html:
Set in a Los Angeles sweatshop warehouse at the height of the underground rave scene of the 1990s, “The Miraculous Mixes of DJ Santa Cecilia” imagines an alternate history where a congregation of indigenous immigrants are introduced to electronic dance music (EDM) in sacred ceremony mixing tribal traditions with industrial techno beats near the end of the millennium. 

Written by Amalia Ortiz, directed by Robin LaVerne “Dragonfly” Wilson.

Choreographer: Rosa "Rosie" Torres: Over the last 30 years, Rosie’s career includes dance teacher, dance artist, choreographer, movement analyst, dance consultant, former dance studio owner, dance curator, and rehearsal director.  Rosie has had extensive outreach with her many roles. Teaching pre-kinder through senior citizens and professionals to non-dancers. She has had the honor of teaching for Marching Auxiliaries of America, the San Antonio Ballet School, Urban 15 Group, the McNay Art Museum Family Days, UTSA doctoral ILT program, UTSA Urban Bird Project, plus numerous dance studios, including high school, university and college dance teams across the United States.

For more information about the production please contact:

Jorge Piña GCAC Theater Arts Director

jorgep@guadalupeculturalarts.org

Clint Taylor GCAC Theater Arts Assistant

clintt@guadalupeculturalarts.org

20260520-a-different-kind-of-silence-by-.title: A Different Kind of Silence by The Vortex
20260520-a-different-kind-of-silence-by-.rss_description_html:
Performed simultaneously in signed ASL and spoken English, Another Kind of Silence examines relationships shaped by difference. Deaf, hard-of-hearing, and hearing characters are paired with a “chorus” - another voice, another body - revealing interior thoughts and emotional truths through a second language. Layered communication and embodied storytelling drive the work, expanding the possibilities of bilingual theatre while centering collective well-being.

The characters’ intersecting stories move through love, fulfillment, hunger, and silence, tracing their journeys as they search for a way forward. What is signed, what is spoken, and what is left unspoken forms a richly textured theatrical language of transformation.

NOTE: signed ASL and spoken English are fully integrated into every performance. 

The VORTEX continues its “Pursuit of Happiness” season with the Rolling World Premiere of Another Kind of Silence, a new bilingual play in English and ASL (American Sign Language) by L M Feldman, directed by MoMo Holt. A National New Play Network (NNPN) Rolling World Premiere, this production unites Deaf, hard-of-hearing, and hearing artists and audiences into a fully integrated bilingual experience.

CREATIVE TEAM: Playwright: L M Feldman. Guest Director: MoMo Holt. Assistant Directors: Taylor Flanagan and Kerry Cooler. Assistant Director of Artistic Sign Language (DASL): JoAnn Benefield. Intimacy Director: Andy Grapko.

PRODUCTION TEAM: Stage Management: Monica Kurtz and Tamara L. Farley. Assistant Stage Management: Liz Ross and Tim Ervin. Script Supervisor: Deb Streusand. Associate Artistic Direction, Dramaturg, and Symposium Direction: Rudy Ramirez. Managing Director, Melissa McKnight. Producing Artistic Director, Bonnie Cullum. 

DESIGN TEAM: Scenic Designer: Izzy Poehlmann. Lighting Designer: Amy Lewis. Costume Designer: Desiree Humphries. Sound Designer: Johann Solo. Projection Designer: Enrique Gomez. Hair and Makeup Design by Ivy Vidal. Prop Design by Jamie Caroll. 

ASL-ENGLISH INTERPRETING TEAM: Cristian Matoon, Tresa Beard, Tim Ervin, and others.

CAST: H. Pavey as ANA, TL Forsburg as CHAP, Shasparay as EVAN, Day West as PETER, Jelena Stojiljkovic Rhynes as ANA’S CHORUS, Jesse Peña as CHAP’S CHORUS, Heba Toulan as EVAN’S CHORUS, and Brian Andrew Cheslik as PETER’S CHORUS. 

The VORTEX, Austin’s long-standing home for new theatre, has a 15-year history of ASL-interpretation of theatre and is the ideal place to foster the growth and deepening of these relationships. Working alongside ArtSpark Texas, Deaf Austin Theatre, and the Texas School for the Deaf this production will expand opportunities for future collaborations. 

CREDITS: For more than two years, with support from The Venturous Theatre Fund and National New Play Network (NNPN) grants, this play was developed through NNPN in collaboration with City Theatre (Pittsburgh, PA), Curious Theatre (Denver, CO), and The VORTEX (Austin, TX), in that sequence. 

The Venturous Playwright Fellowship at the Playwrights’ Center (Minneapolis, MN) funded Another Kind of Silence to be translated into ASL and workshopped under the leadership of MoMo Holt, the original DASL, who created the notated ASL gloss for the script. The play was first produced at City Theatre in early fall 2025, directed by Kim Weild, with MoMo Holt serving as DASL and Clare Drobot, Artistic Director of City Theatre, serving as dramaturg.

Another Kind of Silence is supported in part by VORTEX Repertory Company, a District Grant from the Texas Commission on the Arts, Venturous Theater Fund of the Tides Foundation, The Shubert Foundation, the National New Play Network, the City of Austin Economic Development Department, Six Square Austin’s Black Cultural District, and ATX Theatre. 

—--------------------

L M Feldman (Playwright) is a queer, feminist, GNC playwright who writes theatrically audacious, physically kinetic, ensemble-driven plays that are both epic & intimate. Plays about the women & queers in the margins. Plays that shift the prism. Plays that quest & grapple. Plays that explode space & time & dramaturgical form. Plays that seek to create a communally transcendent experience – for those both onstage & off. Recent plays include: S P A C E (Central Square Theater); HAND FOOT HAND (Playwrights Realm); LIMBER, A LOVE STORY (Emerson Stage); THRIVE, OR WHAT YOU WILL [AN EPIC] (American Shakespeare Center); SCRIBE, OR THE SISTERS MILTON, OR ELEGY FOR THE UNWRITTEN (Playwrights’ Center); and ANOTHER KIND OF SILENCE (City Theater Company); among others. L is ongoingly thankful to have been a Venturous Playwright Fellow & a Core Writer at the Playwrights’ Center, 

a finalist for the FEWW Prize & the Lambda Literary Award for LGBTQ Drama, and a nominee for the Herb Alpert Award, Wendy Wasserstein Prize, Barrie & Bernice Stavis Playwright Award, Doric Wilson Independent Playwright Award, & Susan Smith Blackburn Prize. A movement artist by trade, L spent a decade performing duo trapeze at festivals around the world, and they continue to teach both playwriting & circus dramaturgy around the country. L is passionate about theater that MOVES, and circus that DELVES. L has lived in seven cities and is based in Philadelphia, where they write, collaborate, advocate, teach, and handstand.

MoMo Holt (Director) is an acclaimed actor, director, playwright, Certified Deaf Interpreter (CDI), and Director of Artistic Sign Language (DASL), whose work centers Deaf-led, bilingual theatre with “access-built-in” every stage of the artistic process. She is a professor in the Performing Arts Program at Gallaudet University, where her teaching and scholarship advance inclusive performance practices, Universal Design in Theatrical Presentation, VGC-centered (Visual Gestural Communication) storytelling, and translation for performance. MoMo has been deeply involved in the development and life of Another Kind of Silence, originating the role of ANA and performing in all three major workshops: The Drama League’s New Directors/New Works program in New York City (2013), PlayPenn in Philadelphia (2016), and the Colorado New Play Summit in Denver (2020). She later served for a full year as DASL for the production at City Theatre (Pittsburgh), where she led all ASL translation; provided Deaf-centered dramaturgy; guided the production’s engagement with Deaf and hard-of-hearing cultures; and coached both Deaf and hearing actors in ASL performance, bilingual storytelling, access aesthetics, and culturally responsive collaboration. In this same production, she also performed as Peter’s Chorus. She holds a BFA in Acting from NYU Tisch School of the Arts and an MFA in Theatre from Towson University, and is a member of the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society.

CREATIVE TEAM: Playwright: L M Feldman. Guest Director: MoMo Holt. Assistant Directors: Taylor Flanagan and Kerry Cooler. Assistant Director of Artistic Sign Language (DASL): JoAnn Benefield. Intimacy Director: Andy Grapko. PRODUCTION TEAM: Stage Management: Monica Kurtz and Tamara L. Farley. Assistant Stage Management: Liz Ross and Tim Ervin. Script Supervisor: Deb Streusand. Associate Artistic Direction, Dramaturg, and Symposium Direction: Rudy Ramirez. Managing Director, Melissa McKnight. Producing Artistic Director, Bonnie Cullum. DESIGN TEAM: Scenic Designer: Izzy Poehlmann. Lighting Designer: Amy Lewis. Costume Designer: Desiree Humphries. Sound Designer: Johann Solo. Projection Designer: Enrique Gomez. Hair and Makeup Design by Ivy Vidal. Prop Design by Jamie Caroll. ASL-ENGLISH INTERPRETING TEAM: Cristian Matoon, Tresa Beard, Tim Ervin, and others. CAST: H. Pavey as ANA, TL Forsburg as CHAP, Shasparay as EVAN, Day West as PETER, Jelena Stojiljkovic Rhynes as ANA’S CHORUS, Jesse Peña as CHAP’S CHORUS, Heba Toulan as EVAN’S CHORUS, and Brian Andrew Cheslik as PETER’S CHORUS. The VORTEX, Austin’s long-standing home for new theatre, has a 15-year history of ASL-interpretation of theatre and is the ideal place to foster the growth and deepening of these relationships. Working alongside ArtSpark Texas, Deaf Austin Theatre, and the Texas School for the Deaf this production will expand opportunities for future collaborations. CREDITS: For more than two years, with support from The Venturous Theatre Fund and National New Play Network (NNPN) grants, this play was developed through NNPN in collaboration with City Theatre (Pittsburgh, PA), Curious Theatre (Denver, CO), and The VORTEX (Austin, TX), in that sequence. The Venturous Playwright Fellowship at the Playwrights’ Center (Minneapolis, MN) funded Another Kind of Silence to be translated into ASL and workshopped under the leadership of MoMo Holt, the original DASL, who created the notated ASL gloss for the script. The play was first produced at City Theatre in early fall 2025, directed by Kim Weild, with MoMo Holt serving as DASL and Clare Drobot, Artistic Director of City Theatre, serving as dramaturg. Another Kind of Silence is supported in part by VORTEX Repertory Company, a District Grant from the Texas Commission on the Arts, Venturous Theater Fund of the Tides Foundation, The Shubert Foundation, the National New Play Network, the City of Austin Economic Development Department, Six Square Austin’s Black Cultural District, and ATX Theatre. —-------------------- L M Feldman (Playwright) is a queer, feminist, GNC playwright who writes theatrically audacious, physically kinetic, ensemble-driven plays that are both epic & intimate. Plays about the women & queers in the margins. Plays that shift the prism. Plays that quest & grapple. Plays that explode space & time & dramaturgical form. Plays that seek to create a communally transcendent experience – for those both onstage & off. Recent plays include: S P A C E (Central Square Theater); HAND FOOT HAND (Playwrights Realm); LIMBER, A LOVE STORY (Emerson Stage); THRIVE, OR WHAT YOU WILL [AN EPIC] (American Shakespeare Center); SCRIBE, OR THE SISTERS MILTON, OR ELEGY FOR THE UNWRITTEN (Playwrights’ Center); and ANOTHER KIND OF SILENCE (City Theater Company); among others. L is ongoingly thankful to have been a Venturous Playwright Fellow & a Core Writer at the Playwrights’ Center, a finalist for the FEWW Prize & the Lambda Literary Award for LGBTQ Drama, and a nominee for the Herb Alpert Award, Wendy Wasserstein Prize, Barrie & Bernice Stavis Playwright Award, Doric Wilson Independent Playwright Award, & Susan Smith Blackburn Prize. A movement artist by trade, L spent a decade performing duo trapeze at festivals around the world, and they continue to teach both playwriting & circus dramaturgy around the country. L is passionate about theater that MOVES, and circus that DELVES. L has lived in seven cities and is based in Philadelphia, where they write, collaborate, advocate, teach, and handstand. MoMo Holt (Director) is an acclaimed actor, director, playwright, Certified Deaf Interpreter (CDI), and Director of Artistic Sign Language (DASL), whose work centers Deaf-led, bilingual theatre with “access-built-in” every stage of the artistic process. She is a professor in the Performing Arts Program at Gallaudet University, where her teaching and scholarship advance inclusive performance practices, Universal Design in Theatrical Presentation, VGC-centered (Visual Gestural Communication) storytelling, and translation for performance. MoMo has been deeply involved in the development and life of Another Kind of Silence, originating the role of ANA and performing in all three major workshops: The Drama League’s New Directors/New Works program in New York City (2013), PlayPenn in Philadelphia (2016), and the Colorado New Play Summit in Denver (2020). She later served for a full year as DASL for the production at City Theatre (Pittsburgh), where she led all ASL translation; provided Deaf-centered dramaturgy; guided the production’s engagement with Deaf and hard-of-hearing cultures; and coached both Deaf and hearing actors in ASL performance, bilingual storytelling, access aesthetics, and culturally responsive collaboration. In this same production, she also performed as Peter’s Chorus. She holds a BFA in Acting from NYU Tisch School of the Arts and an MFA in Theatre from Towson University, and is a member of the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society.

20260513-educating-rita-by-100a-producti.title: Educating Rita by 100A Productions
20260513-educating-rita-by-100a-producti.venue_address: inside the Tobin Center 100 Auditorium Circle San Antonio, TX, 78205
20260513-educating-rita-by-100a-producti.rss_description_html:
Educating Rita by Willy Russell is a lively and inspiring play about personal transformation and the power of education. Rita, a spirited working-class woman, enrolls in a university course to escape the confines of her life and find herself. Her tutor, Frank, a jaded academic, is initially skeptical, but as their unlikely relationship deepens, both their lives are changed in unexpected ways.

Packed with humor, heart, and sharp insights, Educating Rita explores themes of self-discovery, ambition, and the journey to break free from societal expectations. It's a vibrant, uplifting story that will leave you reflecting on the power of knowledge and the courage to change your own path.

20260615-doubt-by-100a-productions.title: Doubt by 100A Productions
20260615-doubt-by-100a-productions.venue_address: inside the Tobin Center 100 Auditorium Circle San Antonio, TX, 78205
20260615-doubt-by-100a-productions.rss_description_html:
In this brilliant and powerful drama, Sister Aloysius, a Bronx school principal, takes matters into her own hands when she suspects the young Father Flynn of improper relations with one of the male students.

  • “All the elements come invigoratingly together like clockwork in John Patrick Shanley’s provocative new play, Doubt, a gripping story of suspicion cast on a priest’s behavior that is less about scandal than about fascinatingly nuanced questions of moral certainty. Something rare for this season: a laudable new American play.” — Variety
  • “How splendid it feels to be trusted with such passionate, exquisite ambiguity unlike anything we have seen from this prolific playwright so far. Blunt yet subtle, manipulative but full of empathy for all sides, the play is set in 1964 but could not be more timely. In just ninety fast-moving minutes, Shanley creates four blazingly individual people. Doubt is a lean, potent drama…passionate, exquisite, important and engrossing.” — Newsday (NY)
  • “A beautifully balanced drama. Shanley is a writer working at the top of his craft, making the most of a muted but evocative palette in the pursuit of truth’s shadows. Here, for the first time in a long time, is a play that is about something.” — Chicago Tribune
  • “An eloquent and provocative investigation of truth and consequences. A gripping mystery, tightly written.” — Time Out New York

Industry Night Reading

What is an Industry Night Reading?

This staged reading invites you into the creative process. Actors perform with scripts in hand, stage directions are spoken aloud, and the focus is on the words, the ideas, and the spark of something new. Your presence helps shape what could become the next fully realized production.

20260126-the-realistic-joneses-by-100a-p.title: The Realistic Joneses by 100A Productions
20260126-the-realistic-joneses-by-100a-p.venue_address: inside the Tobin Center 100 Auditorium Circle San Antonio, TX, 78205
20260126-the-realistic-joneses-by-100a-p.rss_description_html:
Meet Bob and Jennifer and their new neighbors John and Pony, two suburban couples who have more in common than their identical last names. Boasting the playwright's quintessential existential quirkiness, this comedy finds poetry in the banal while humorously exploring our ever-floundering efforts at communication. Listed as one of New York Times's Best Plays of 2012, The Realistic Joneses received its Broadway premiere in 2014. 

Directed by Stacey Connelly

"Eno’s dialogue is a marvel of compression and tonal control, trivial chitchat flipping into cosmic profundity with striking ease [...] there’s much to savor: the dry but meaningful banter, the joy of humans sharing time and space, battling the darkness with a joke or silence. Life in Enoland isn’t what you’d call realistic — it’s more real than that." - Time Out New York

"[...] each line is sharply refined with dry wit and packed with underlying meaning. The characters are written with impressive realism [...]" - The Oregonian

"Will Eno has written a play of such extraordinary wit and insight, so carefully constructed, it resonates for days. Lines of dialogue peal through your thoughts like distant bells." - Edge Media 

 
“Trivial chitchat flipping into cosmic profundity with striking ease.” — Time Out New York
 
Industry Night Reading
What is an Industry Night Reading?
This staged reading invites you into the creative process. Actors perform with scripts in hand, stage directions are spoken aloud, and the focus is on the words, the ideas, and the spark of something new. Your presence helps shape what could become the next fully realized production.
 
Join us Monday, January 26 for an intimate night of theater, conversation, and discovery.

20260327-hedwig-and-the-angry-inch-by-au.title: Hedwig and the Angry Inch by Austin Rainbow Theatre (ART)
20260327-hedwig-and-the-angry-inch-by-au.rss_description_html:
Hedwig and the Angry Inch is a groundbreaking punk rock musical that confronts identity, belonging, and survival with ferocity, humor, and heart. Told through a live concert, the show follows Hedwig, an East German immigrant and glam-rock singer, with a sharp tongue, a tender heart, and a story that refuses to stay quiet.

 

Packed with iconic songs like “The Origin of Love,” “Wig in a Box,” “Sugar Daddy,” and “Midnight Radio,” the musical careens between biting humor and unexpected vulnerability. This Tony Award-winning musical skewers fame, love, heartbreak, and identity with equal parts glitter, grit, and defiance, turning personal trauma into a full-throttle act of survival.

 

In this moment—when queer and trans lives are increasingly politicized and threatened—Hedwig and the Angry Inch feels both urgent and defiant. The show refuses shame and insists on visibility, autonomy, and joy as acts of resistance. With its raw storytelling and iconic rock score, the musical becomes a space for collective catharsis, reminding us that self-definition is not only necessary, but revolutionary.

20260220-the-minutes-by-gaslight-baker-t.title: The Minutes by Gaslight Baker Theatre
20260220-the-minutes-by-gaslight-baker-t.rss_description_html: Step into the council chambers of Big Cherry, a small town with big secrets, where civic pride meets civic panic and every polite smile hides a sharper truth. Tracy Letts’ Tony-nominated dark comedy pulls you into a city council meeting that starts routine and veers into chaos as missing members, questionable traditions, and fiercely guarded local “history” collide. The Minutes is fast, sharp, hilarious, and unsettling, a satire that punches upward and exposes how far people will go to protect the stories they choose to believe.

20260220-hadestown-by-touring-company.title: Hadestown by touring company
20260220-hadestown-by-touring-company.rss_description_html:
HADESTOWN intertwines two mythic tales — that of young dreamers Orpheus and Eurydice, and that of King Hades and his wife Persephone — as it invites you on a hell-raising journey to the underworld and back. Mitchell’s beguiling melodies and Chavkin’s poetic imagination pit industry against nature, doubt against faith, and fear against love.

Performed by a vibrant ensemble of actors, dancers and singers, HADESTOWN is a haunting and hopeful theatrical experience that grabs you and never lets go.

20260227-the-importance-of-being-earnest.title: The Importance of Being Earnest by Crystal Sea Drama Company
20260227-the-importance-of-being-earnest.rss_description_html:
Two young men and two young women try to navigate their families’ Victorian-era expectations of courtship, all the while engaging in a battle of wits. When the young men’s names and egos collide, the pair get caught up in romantic snafus and mistaken identities, while the young women slide from bosom friends to sworn enemies and back again. Oscar Wilde called his play a “trivial comedy for serious people.” It reveals the absurd lengths people will go to for love and acceptance and is considered a comedic classic. Suitable for all ages.

CSDC alumna Julianna Martin,directs Oscar Wilde’s classic comedy of manners.

20260202-wit-by-texas-lutheran-universit.title: Wit by Texas Lutheran University Dramatic Media
20260202-wit-by-texas-lutheran-universit.rss_description_html:
Margaret Edson's powerfully imagined Pulitzer Prize–winning play examines what makes life worth living through her exploration of one of existence's unifying experiences―mortality―while she also probes the vital importance of human relationships. What we as her audience take away from this remarkable drama is a keener sense that, while death is real and unavoidable, our lives are ours to cherish or throw away―a lesson that can be both uplifting and redemptive.
 
As the playwright herself puts it, "The play is not about doctors or even about cancer. It's about kindness, but it shows arrogance. It's about compassion, but it shows insensitivity."

20260131-snacked-up-in-prayer-by-jump-st.title: Snacked Up in Prayer by Jump-Start Performance Company
20260131-snacked-up-in-prayer-by-jump-st.html_synopsis: Until the day she got ‘that’ fateful phone call, Dragonfly was living her best bohemian life in NYC. Now, after 20 years, the prodigal daughter is back in her childhood home in Texas. She negotiates the changes in her octogenarian mother’s memories and abilities while also dealing with her own change of life and change of circumstances. Helpful and harmful characters aid and assail her on her journey. As the baby of the family, she quickly learns to care for her mother and herself beyond everyone’s expectations, with the help of snacks and prayers along the way.

20260206-pride-and-prejudice-munsil-by-c.title: Pride and Prejudice (Munsil) by Chambers Theatre Company
20260206-pride-and-prejudice-munsil-by-c.venue_address: 121 N. Main Street Inspired Minds Arts Center Buda, TX, 78710
20260206-pride-and-prejudice-munsil-by-c.rss_description_html:
More than 200 years after the novel first appeared in print, Janet Munsil's witty, romantic, and ingenious adaptation of Jane Austen's beloved tale of the independent-minded Elizabeth Bennet and enigmatic Mr Darcy is remarkable for capturing the tone and compressing the complexity of the story into a fast-paced, funny, and fiercely romantic two hours on stage. This adaptation is highly popular with schools and community theatres for its clarity, comedy, and large number of great acting roles - especially for women.
 
Janet Munsil's sparkling stage adaptation of Jane Austen's classic tale of love, family, and the politics of marriage premiered in 2012 in a co-production between two of Canada's most prestigious companies, Theatre Calgary and Canada's National Arts Centre (Ottawa). Audiences fell head over heels in love with this fresh new version of the iconic romance, which sold out its runs in both cities and attracted ardent admiration from theatre critics.
 
Directed by Bridget Gates

20260522-puffs-or-seven-increasingly-eve.title: PUFFS (or Seven Increasingly Eventful Years at a Certain School of Magic & Magic) by Bastrop Opera House
20260522-puffs-or-seven-increasingly-eve.rss_description_html: For seven years, a certain boy wizard had adventures at a certain school of magic. This… is not his story. Puffs tells the hilarious tale of the underdog house—the one full of kind, loyal misfits just trying to make it through magic school without losing points or getting eaten. A fast-paced, clever, and heartfelt parody for anyone who ever felt like the sidekick.

20260220-the-trip-to-bountiful-by-city-t.title: The Trip to Bountiful by City Theatre Company
20260220-the-trip-to-bountiful-by-city-t.venue_address: Genesis Creative Collective 1507 Wilshire Blvd Austin, TX, 78722
20260220-the-trip-to-bountiful-by-city-t.rss_description_html:
"I guess when you’ve lived longer than your house and family, then you’ve lived long enough." – Mrs. Carrie Watts, The Trip to Bountiful 

 

The Trip to Bountiful is the acclaimed play by Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, Horton Foote, and the American masterpiece about the universal pull that we all feel for home. Carrie Watts is an elderly widow, held close by her overprotective son and domineering daughter-in-law, who longs the return to her hometown of Bountiful one last time before she dies. With pension check in hand, and a heart yearning to find who she once was, she breaks free for the road home. Her journey is the rarest of theater experiences, filled with humor and tenderness that’s both touching and life-affirming.

 

"I believe very deeply in the human spirit, and I have a sense of awe about it. – Horton Foote

 

Kicking off the 2026 theatre season, City Theatre is thrilled to present for its first time, a production by the distinguished Texas-born playwright Horton Foote. His acclaimed play, The Trip to Bountiful will run February 20 – March 8 at Genesis Creative Collective.

The production is directed by guest director Tracy Arnold, and features the cast of Judith Laird as Mrs. Carrie Watts, Beau Paul, Dawn Erin, Olivia Jamison, Ken Farrell, and Austin Lytle.

The work and literary success of American – and Texas born - playwright and screenwriter, Horton Foote, spans the course of 80 years. Growing up in Wharton, Texas, Foote had big dreams of being an actor. He lived in Dallas with his grandmother while working as an usher at the Majestic Theater and moved to California, enrolling in acting school at Pasadena Playhouse. Only the Heart was Foote’s first play on Broadway at the Bijou Theatre in 1944. Evoking American life in beautifully observed minimal stories of family loss and love, his theatre works has been produced worldwide.

New York Times chief theater critic Frank Rich described Foote as “a major American dramatist whose epic body of work recalls Chekhov in its quotidian comedy and heartbreak and Faulkner in its ability to make his own corner of America stand for the whole.”

Foote’s theatrical honors include a Pulitzer Prize for The Young Man from Atlanta; Lucille Lortel Awards for The Orphans Home Cycle and The Trip to Bountiful; and an OBIE award for Dividing the Estate. His screenwriting honors include Oscars for To Kill a Mockingbird and Tender Mercies; an Emmy for Old Man; and the Writers Guild of America awards for To Kill a Mockingbird and Tender Mercies. Foote was also a member of the Theatre Hall of Fame, the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and a recipient of the National Medal of Arts.

Horton Foote passed away in his sleep in 2009 at the age of ninety-two. 

 

Celebrating its 20th Anniversary Season, City Theatre is an Austin-based, not-for-profit arts organization and is sponsored in part by the Austin Creative Alliance and the Cultural Arts Division of the City of Austin. Founded in 2006, the company has been recognized by the Austin Critics Table Awards, the B. Iden Payne Awards, the Central Texas Excellence in Theatre Awards, BroadwayWorld Austin, Central Texas Live Theatre, and has twice been voted “Best Theatre Company” by Austin American-Statesman’s Austin 360. CTC is dedicated to providing a quality, reputable, and diverse public theatre and stage entertainment experience that is accessible to all artists and the entire Austin community. CTC continues to offer its student and group discount ticket program for any show.

 Put a little theatre in your life!

20260220-sweeney-todd-by-nesa-northeast-.title: Sweeney Todd by NESA Northeast School of the Arts
20260220-sweeney-todd-by-nesa-northeast-.venue_address: Robert E. Lee High School 1400 Jackson Keller San Antonio, TX, 78213
20260220-sweeney-todd-by-nesa-northeast-.rss_description_html:
Set in the dark, fog-choked streets of 19th-century London, Sweeney Todd tells the chilling tale of an unjustly exiled barber who returns to seek bloody vengeance against the corrupt judge who destroyed his life. With the help of the practical and delightfully wicked pie shop owner, Mrs. Lovett, Todd opens a new barbershop above her crumbling establishment—and soon discovers a sinister solution to both his need for retribution and Mrs. Lovett's perpetually short supply of meat.

Experience Stephen Sondheim's masterpiece, a gripping and darkly comedic musical thriller that has captivated audiences for decades. This musical features one of the most magnificent and complex scores ever written for the stage, weaving together drama, suspense, and unexpected humor. It is an electrifying journey into obsession and madness that has cemented its place as a cornerstone of modern musical theatre.

Audience Advisory: Mature Content

Please be advised that Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street contains mature themes, stylized violence, and moments of intense psychological tension and horror.

This production is not suitable for small children. We recommend this show for audiences aged 14 and older. Parental discretion is strongly advised for all patrons.

20260123-rara-avis-by-ishida-dance-compa.title: Rara Avis by Ishida Dance Company
20260123-rara-avis-by-ishida-dance-compa.rss_description_html:
Rara avis which means “rare bird” in Latin is a highly physical, visually stunning and emotionally resonant international program with critically acclaimed dancers and choreography. The world premiere of Rara avis by ISHIDA follows a singer who struggles with imposter syndrome as she returns to stage after taking a hiatus.

Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?—a painting by Paul Gauguin in 1897, depicts disparate states of being. 

Like Gaugin’s painting, Ishida Dance Company prompts existential questions through dreamscapes that celebrate universal themes of our psyche—betrayal, belonging, loss and love. 

Ishida Dance Company presents world-class contemporary dance performances consisting of new works by choreographers that are innovative and unique experimenting with dance and contemporary narratives in dance theatre to support accessibility for audiences to gather meaning in performances. Such programming extends an invitation towards introspection and embracing Otherness. 

The program includes Mutual Comfort by world renowned Romanian choreographer Edward Clug and a new dance theater work by award-winning British Finnish choreographer Kristian Lever. The evening promises to be a unique opportunity to see some of the best and most interesting choreography from Europe and the U.S.

20260319-lend-me-a-tenor-by-la-bete-prod.title: Lend Me A Tenor by La Bête Productions
20260319-lend-me-a-tenor-by-la-bete-prod.venue_address: 702 Donaldson Avenue (directly opposite Jefferson High School) San Antonio, TX, 78201
20260319-lend-me-a-tenor-by-la-bete-prod.rss_description_html:
This Tony Award–winning master comedy by Ken Ludwig delivers big laughs in a nonstop farce. Expect mistaken identities, outrageous surprises, and larger-than-life characters. You'll have a "suite" experience from the moment you walk into the theater! A night at the opera turns into a run-around, costume-wearing, zany farce with mistaken identities and a whole lot of laughs.

Lend Me a Tenor follows Max, a lowly production assistant with big opera dreams, who’s tasked with handling the world-renowned opera star, Tito Mirrelli, leading up to his American premiere at the Cleveland Grand Opera House. But when Tito becomes unable to perform, Max and his boss unfold an elaborate scheme to fool all of Cleveland with a Tito Mirrelli lookalike. One too many women start coming in and out of the hotel suite mistaking one person for another. The confusion leads to a madcap comedy that unravels a ridiculous plan on the verge of ruining careers and becoming a scandal that will rock the opera world.

“This has always been one of my favorite comedies. A revival of Ken Ludwig’s work is overdo in San Antonio,” says Blake Hamman, director of the play. “Lend Me a Tenor takes place in a hotel suite in the 30s, and we have ideas on how to bring the audience in on the fun. They’re going to feel they’re in on the experience the moment they walk into the building.

20260424-is-god-is-by-broke-thespians-th.title: Is God Is by Broke Thespians Theatre Company
20260424-is-god-is-by-broke-thespians-th.html_synopsis: Twenty-one-year-old African-American twin sisters Racine and Anaia were burned and scarred as babies. Racine has burn scars on her arms, back, and neck, and Anaia has scars on her arms, face, and neck. After receiving a letter in their apartment in Northeast, they journey to the Dirty South to the deathbed of their mother, who is known as "SHE" or "God" and has scars all over her body. SHE informs them that their father, referred to as “Man”, set the fire that burned the three of them. SHE instructs the sisters to go west to The Valley to find and kill him for revenge. The sisters travel to The Valley to face Man and his new family.

20260214-nuestras-historias-by-teatro-au.title: Nuestras Historias by Teatro Audaz
20260214-nuestras-historias-by-teatro-au.venue_address: 1310 S. Brazos St San Antonio, TX, 78207
20260214-nuestras-historias-by-teatro-au.rss_description_html:
We’re excited to officially announce the directors and associate directors for our 3rd Annual Nuestras Historias New Play Workshop. This incredible group of artists will help bring powerful new works by local playwrights to life—centering community, cultura, and fearless storytelling.

 

Puro Pastorela by Becka Morton

Directed by Angel Avila

Stage managed by Lucas Collins

 

The Dangerous History of La Lotería by C.M. Bratton

Directed by Cindy Rodriguez-Martinez

Stage managed by Lucas Collins

 

The Three Curses by Adrian Gonzales

Directed by Lili Sanchez

Associate Director: Briana Morales

Stage managed by Angel Avila

 

Storytime With Abuelita by Patricia Zamora

Directed by Mason Ortiz

Associate Director: Austin Escobedo

Stage managed by Angel Avila

 

Please join us in celebrating these artists and the stories they’ll be stewarding this February and March.

Nuestras Historias 2026

20260321-swing-state-by-the-surround-pro.title: Swing State by The Surround Project
20260321-swing-state-by-the-surround-pro.venue_address: 20318 Huebner Rd, Suite 125 San Antonio, TX, 78258
20260321-swing-state-by-the-surround-pro.rss_description_html:
It’s hard to know who your friends are in a world that’s more divided than ever.

 Recently widowed, Peg tends to the native plants in her 40-acre rural Wisconsin prairie backyard, her solitary days interrupted only by visits from a family friend with a checkered past. When a mysterious theft alerts the authorities, a string of events unfolds that forever changes their lives. Pulitzer Prize finalist playwright Rebecca Gilman pens a contemporary portrait of America’s heartland in a time when it feels like everyone’s way of life is in danger of disappearing.

             Swing State “is perhaps the first of the great American post-COVID plays” (Chris Jones, Chicago Tribune).

Join Surround Project for our next Play Date, a one-night-only staged reading that feels social. Enjoy beverages, snacks, surrounding activities, and conversation while experiencing a notable contemporary play that has never been seen in San Antonio.

Run time: Approximately 105 minutes.

Swing State premiered at Goodman Theatre (Chicago) in 2022 and later played Off-Broadway, earning multiple Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle Award nominations.

Each Play Date includes:

  • A staged reading with complimentary bevvies
  • A San Antonio premiere of a notable contemporary play

 

PLAY DATE PRODUCERS | Catherine Babbitt, Susan Briedenbach, Anna Gangai & Bruce Liesman, and Diane Malone

Swing State premiered at Goodman Theatre (Chicago) in 2022 and later played Off-Broadway, earning multiple Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle Award nominations. Each Play Date includes: A staged reading with complimentary bevvies A San Antonio premiere of a notable contemporary play PLAY DATE PRODUCERS | Catherine Babbitt, Susan Briedenbach, Anna Gangai & Bruce Liesman, and Diane Malone

20260426-the-importance-of-being-earnest.title: The Importance of Being Earnest by Milam Community Theatre
20260426-the-importance-of-being-earnest.venue_name: Lester and Beatrice Williams Events Center at 408 S. Columbus Ave. in Cameron
20260426-the-importance-of-being-earnest.html_synopsis: Two young gentlemen living in 1890's England have taken to bending the truth in order to put some excitement into their lives. Jack Worthing has invented a brother, Earnest, whom he uses as an excuse to leave his dull country life behind to visit the ravishing Gwendolyn. Algy Montcrieff decided to take the name 'Earnest' when visiting Worthing's young and beautiful ward, Cecily at the country manor. Things start to go awry when they end up together in country and their deceptions are discovered - threatening to spoil their romantic pursuits.

20260226-yoke-by-dirty-gold-theatre.title: Yoke by Dirty Gold Theatre
20260226-yoke-by-dirty-gold-theatre.venue_address: somewhere in Austin to be announced Austin, TX, 78700
20260226-yoke-by-dirty-gold-theatre.rss_description_html:
YOKEis a dark comedy about five strangers who gather for a weekend wellness retreat that promises transformation without explaining how. Through a series of increasingly unsettling tasks, the group is pushed toward confession, conflict, and moments of unexpected self-reflection and mutual understanding.

This production was created through a fully devised process, with the ensemble building the play collaboratively from the ground up. Guided by the theme of sonder (the awareness that everyone has a rich inner life) the company generated material through discussion, movement, improvisation, and reflection, shaping it together into a one-hour performance. As with all Dirty Gold Theatre projects, the process was mindfulness-based, incorporating meditations, physical warm-ups, and regular check-ins to support both artistic risk-taking and collective care.

Directed by Rebecca Greaves

Written by Roy Lazorwitz & Meret Slover

Devised & performed by Julius Alums, Kahla Brown, Joe Kelley, Chrissy Pace, Stephanie Salama

Yoke (noun): from the Sanskrit root yuj, meaning “to join” or “to unite,” which is also the origin of the word yoga—referring to the act of binding, joining, or bringing together, whether bodies, minds, or beings.

20260327-men-on-boats-by-city-theatre-co.title: Men on Boats by City Theatre Company
20260327-men-on-boats-by-city-theatre-co.venue_address: Genesis Creative Collective 1507 Wilshire Blvd Austin, TX, 78722
20260327-men-on-boats-by-city-theatre-co.rss_description_html: Ten explorers. Four boats. One Big-Ass Canyon. Boats The true(ish) history of an 1869 expedition, when a one-armed captain and a crew of insane yet loyal misfits set out to chart the course of the Colorado River. With a gender-bent cast, this innovative plays offers a fresh perspective on the American West and the nature of adventure itself. With humor, heart, and a thrilling narrative, it is unconventional storytelling that creates a unique and thrilling theatrical experience.

20260304-short-shakespeare-three-plays-b.title: Short Shakespeare - Three plays by Walking Shadow Shakespeare
20260304-short-shakespeare-three-plays-b.venue_address: Black Box Theatre, 4th floor, First Baptist Church 901 Trinity Street Austin, TX, 78701
20260304-short-shakespeare-three-plays-b.rss_description_html:
Walking Shadow Shakespeare Project is thrilled to announce a night of three short plays inspired by Shakespeare. The evening will feature new works: I Loved You Ever by Pablo Muñoz-Evers (he/him) and Puck, in Epilogue by Amber Elby (she/her) as well as a new adaptation of a classic: Macbeth, But He’s Just A Sword.

I Loved You Ever, directed by Kennedy Thompson (she/they), features Andrew Springer (any/all) as Hamlet, Divine Ntomchukwu (he/him) as Laertes, and Laura D’Eramo (she/her) as Yorick. This emotionally captivating piece takes a moment of Hamlet out of time as Hamlet and Laertes examine their feelings for one another and the barriers between their love. It has humor, heart, and hope - three guiding principles that sometimes fight each other and sometimes are wrapped up in the same line.

Macbeth, But He’s Just A Sword, directed by Andrew Solis (he/him), features a sword Macbeth voiced by Kyle Romero (he/him) controlled by Kaylynn Yarelle (they/them) as Lady Macbeth and the three fate-spinning witches: Samantha Plumb (she/her), Juni Nguyen (she/they), and Mayuri Raja (she/her). Filling out the cast are Lee Vineyard (he/they) as Macduff, Martha Neil (they/them) as Malcolm, Angela Adams (she/her) as Duncan, Sadie Okerstrom (she/her) as Ross, Julien Hemmendinger (he/him) as Banquo, and Oak Novielli (he/any) as Lennox.

Puck, in Epilogue, directed by Mike Crugnola (he/him), features Stephanie Crugnola (she/her) as Puck. After the final soliloquy of A Midsummer Night’s Dream, the hobgoblin Puck has some questions for the audience - and even more for himself. As he grapples with consequences, pride, and love, will Puck finally find himself, or will he be doomed to repeat his prior misdeeds?

 

About Walking Shadow Shakespeare Project

Walking Shadow is a non-profit 501(c)(3) theatre company whose mission is to unite classical texts with a contemporary community through innovative and accessible productions, social events and educational opportunities. We performed our first production Much Ado About Nothing in 2011 in Massachusetts, and since then have mounted full Shakespearean productions across three states, hosted Zoom performances through lockdown, developed one-rehearsal and interactive education show formats, and brought our communities together through community events and workshops.

For more information, please visit walkingshadowshakespeare.com or follow us on instagram @wsshakes.

20260210-treasure-island-lavery-by-texas.title: Treasure Island (Lavery) by Texas State University Department of Theatre, Dance and Film
20260210-treasure-island-lavery-by-texas.venue_address: 601 University Drive Texas State University San Marcos, TX, 78666
20260210-treasure-island-lavery-by-texas.rss_description_html:
On a stormy night at the edge of the world, young Jim Hawkins lives with her sharp-tongued grandmother at the Admiral Benbow Inn. Their quiet life is upended by the arrival of Bill Bones, a haunted pirate with a mysterious sea chest. When Bones dies and leaves behind a cryptic map, Jim is swept into an epic sea voyage aboard the Hispaniola, accompanied by the blustering Squire Trelawney and the practical Doctor Livesey. But danger lurks below deck in the form of Long John Silver, a one-legged cook with secrets of his own. As Jim navigates mutiny, shifting loyalties, and a mysterious island haunted by ghostly memories, she must decide who to trust, and what treasure truly means. Filled with music, dance, puppetry, magic and theatrical invention, Bryony Lavery’s adaptation brings Robert Louis Stevenson’s classic tale to life in a bold and highly imaginative way.

Treasure Island
by Robert Louis Stevenson
Adapted by Bryony Lavery
Directed by Andy Park

This nautical tale features Jordan Rockhill (Jim Hawkins), Rem Remy (Doctor Livesey), Drew Dunson (Squire Trelawney), Cadence Dodd (Red Ruth), Jack Peznola (Lucky Mickey), Miguel Gaytan (Black Dog), Andrew Morataya (Captain Smollett), and Jordan Spena (Long John Silver), Elise Ray (Joan the Goat), Natoz Walker (Israel Hands), Faraz Mobli (Dick the Dandy), Christian Nathaniel (Killigrew the Kind), Mick Preuit (Grey), Jay Brown (Parrot), Sonny Young (Ben Gunn/Blind Pew), Cooper Clarke (Boson) and the talent of faculty members Linda Nenno Briening (Grandma Hawkins) and Neil Patrick Stewart (Bill Bones), and the voice of Ron Ulen (Ghost of Captain Flint).

Treasure Island showcases the creativity and technical skill of SoTDF’s faculty and student designers, technicians, performers, and faculty, offering a high-energy theatrical experience that balances swashbuckling excitement with moments of humor, heart, and suspense. The creative team includes Max Estudillo, scenic designer; Nina Haurani, costume designer; Matt Webb, lighting designer; Catherine Kenner, sound designer; Colin Shay, technical director; Emily Cook, puppet designer; and Marwa Habibi, production stage manager.

20260312-the-last-five-years-by-laredo-t.title: The Last Five Years by Laredo Theatre Guild International
20260312-the-last-five-years-by-laredo-t.venue_address: West End Washington Street Laredo, TX, 78040
20260312-the-last-five-years-by-laredo-t.rss_description_html:
The Last Five Years is a unique musical that tells the poignant love story between Jamie and Cathy. The narrative unfolds in a non-linear fashion, with Jamie's perspective moving forward in time while Cathy's recounts their relationship in reverse. This innovative storytelling beautifully captures the highs and lows of love, ambition, and heartbreak.
Join us on this emotional journey that explores the complexities of relationships through powerful songs and heartfelt moments. Don't miss out on this theatrical gem!

20260220-a-midsummer-nights-dream-by-tex.title: A Midsummer Night's Dream by Texas Lutheran University Dramatic Media
20260220-a-midsummer-nights-dream-by-tex.rss_description_html: If Shakespeare's plays were football teams, this one would have been in a Super Bowl. Don't miss the battles, the combat, the passion, the magic, and yes, the dreams! Are you team Hermia and Lysander? Team Demetrius and Helena? Oberon and Titania? And what happens when they all turn on each other? There may not be any Pucks in the Super Bowl, but there will be one in just under two weeks, played by Dr. Heather Couture!

20260320-prohibition-a-musical-about-the.title: Prohibition, a musical about the War on Booze by Texas Comedies
20260320-prohibition-a-musical-about-the.rss_description_html:
There’s a battle over booze in the Capital City, as a speakeasy owner is pitted against the Anti-Saloon League next door.  This one-hour musical comedy - with a live band - is based on the conflict in Texas between the “Wets” and the “Drys.” 

 Cast includes (in alphabetical order) Dan Dalbout, Max Hanesworth, Lydia Margitza, Aaron Matijasic, Rachel Pallante, Tatyana Smith and Jess Workman.

Prohibition: A Musical Comedy
presented by Texas Comedies
written by John Cecil & Texas Comedies

Texas Comedies, based in Austin, creates and performs original musical comedies throughout Texas.  Recent shows include Crash at Crush, The Feud, Murders & Moontowers, Bonnie & Clyde and Boomtown.
